{{Unreferenced|date=November 2011}} The '''SIRP''' - '''''Sistema de InformaÃ§Ãµes da RepÃºblica Portuguesa''''' (Intelligence System of the Portuguese Republic) is the coordinating structure of Portuguese intelligence.
It is the parent body for two separate intelligence services: the [[SIS]] - [[ServiÃ§os de InformaÃ§Ãµes de SeguranÃ§a|''ServiÃ§o de InformaÃ§Ãµes de SeguranÃ§a'']] (Security Intelligence Service) [[Portugal]]'s [[intelligence agency]] for internal security, and the SIED - ''ServiÃ§o de InformaÃ§Ãµes EstratÃ©gicas de Defesa'' (Defense Strategic Intelligence Service) for foreign [[intelligence]].
The SIS and the SIED are the public services responsible for ensuring - within the [[Constitution of Portugal|Constitution]] and the [[Law of Portugal|law]] - the production of intelligence necessary to the safeguard of the national independence and the safeguard of the internal security.
==History== [[Image:Novobrasao_peq.gifâ|thumb|150px|right|Logo of the SIED.]] During the [[New State (Portugal)|New State regime]] and until its end in 1974, the main intelligence agency in Portugal was the [[PIDE]] - ''PolÃ­cia Internacional e de Defesa do Estado'' (International and State Defense Police). Nominally under jurisdiction of the [[Ministry of the Internal Administration (Portugal)|Ministry of the Interior]], PIDE was in fact a [[secret police]] force controlled directly by [[Portugal|Portuguese]] prime-minister [[AntÃ³nio de Oliveira Salazar]]. In 1968, under Salazar's successor [[Marcello Caetano]], PIDE was renamed the ''DirecÃ§Ã£o Geral de SeguranÃ§a'' (DGS, Directorate General of Security) and underwent some reform. Following a [[Carnation Revolution|coup]] by the [[Military of Portugal|Portuguese military]] in 1974 the agency was immediately abolished due to the abhorrence felt for the PIDE/DGS as a tool of the authoritarian regime.
Because of the memory of the abuses of the PIDE/DGS in supporting the regime the establishment of a new civilian intelligence agency was delayed for more than a decade. However, following a terrorist attack on the [[Embassy]] of [[Turkey]] and the assassination of a [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] representative at a [[Socialist International]] conference in 1983, and a number of domestic terrorist attacks, the [[Government of Portugal|Portuguese government]] became convinced of the need for a new intelligence agency. This led to the establishment of SIRP in 1984.
==Organization== [[Image:SIS 01.png|thumb|150px|right|Logo of the SIS.]] The SIRP is under the direct authority of the [[Prime Minister of Portugal]] and includes: * the Supervisory Council of the SIRP (under the authority of the [[Assembly of the Republic|Portuguese Parliament]]); * the Data Supervisory Committee of the SIRP (under the authority of the [[Public Ministry (Portugal)|Attorney General of Portugal]]); * the Superior Council of Intelligence; * the Secretary General of the SIRP; * the SIED; * the SIS.
The Secretary General - equivalent to a [[Secretary of State#Portugal|secretary of State]] and designated by the Prime-Minister - is the head of the SIRP and coordinates the directors of the SIED and the SIS. It is the inspection, supervision and coordination organ of both the intelligence services.
Directly under the Secretary General is the Administrative and Technical Support Office and the four joint departments of the SIRP (Finance and General Support, Security, Human Resources and Information Technology).
